page.title: 04HOUSES IN POTT SHRIGLEY
page.content: Apart from a small new development on the edge of Bollington, houses in Pott Shrigley are mosty cottages or farm houses built of local stone in the seventeenth and eighteenthcenturies. The area is part of the Peak National Park and strict development policies have ensured sympathetic modernisation and extension of many properties. In the adjacent area of Adlington, which is in the north-east Cheshire green belt, the position is similar but with some use of locally made brick in the lower lying areas. There was a small pre-war ribbon development of large detached houses, some on double plots, allowing for some modern infilling. The individual nature of properties and the unspoilt rural setting makes this a very desirable area for retired people and commuters to settle, with very few working farmhouses remaining.
